title: Can an unbaptized person ever be baptized again?

title: What's the deal with people who say "Allah is watching" when they threaten someone?
self_text: I have noticed it a lot recently, especially online.  People will make threats to someone and then follow up with something like "Allah is watching" or “May Allah guide you”.   I just find it weird and unsettling.  Like, what does that even mean?  Is that some kind of intimidation tactic?  I don’t understand why someone would say that unless they are genuinely trying to scare someone.   I do know that in Islam, there’s a concept of divine justice but it doesn't seem to be used as a means of bullying people.  Anyone else notice this happening?  What do you think about it?

title: What is the most beautiful thing you've ever seen?
self_text: It could be anything, natural or man-made.   I was just thinking about this and it seems like everyone has some sort of example that stands out to them. For me, it's the aurora borealis I saw in Iceland.  It’s hard to describe how overwhelming it felt seeing those colours dance across the sky.  What about you guys? Did anyone else see an incredible thing recently?

title: What if the fire was a sign of God’s will?
self_text: If the fire that consumed the temple in Jerusalem was a sign of God’s will, then it would have been better to let it happen. I believe Jesus was saying this when he said “Destroy this temple, and I shall rebuild it in three days.”   Jesus says that we should destroy his body (the flesh) and he shall build it up again in three days.  The key here is “destroy” which means to take apart, to break down, or to tear down.   When he said, “Destroy this temple,” he didn’t mean to actually physically destroy the temple, but rather, to tear down the religious system.   So what if the fire was a sign of God’s will?   It could have been for several reasons, such as to make us realize that there are things that we can’t control.   However, the fact that the fire was so severe—it burned everything—would have been a way to show us how much we need to be ready for the end times.

title: A few questions about the teaching of Islam in schools
self_text: Hi everyone, I am a teacher in an elementary school and I was wondering about the best ways to teach children about Islam.  I have some students who are Muslim, and they've asked me questions about why Muslims don't eat pork, for example. Also, there is a student whose family has recently converted to Islam and he is asking what a muslim should do with their money.   Do you have any tips on how to respond to these types of questions?   Thanks!

title: What’s your favorite part of the movie?
self_text: It’s kind of a long question, and I want to hear all of your thoughts on it. However, what’s the best part of the movie is your favorite part of the movie?  Is it when the main character goes out on his first date with a girl he likes? Or maybe it’s when he finally realizes that his brother has been lying about being a cop for years? Or maybe it’s just the scene where he gets shot by the bad guy! Whatever it may be, let me know in the comments below.   I can see why some people might have different favorites than others though. Some people might have liked the characters more than the plot, or vice versa. And some people might have just liked the way the movie was made overall. No matter what you think of it, I hope you had fun watching it! This movie is a good one, and I hope you like it as much as I do. The only thing that would have made it better is if the main character had gotten away with everything. That would have been epic!

title: What do you think about the new season of Love is Blind?
self_text: I'm not sure what to think after watching the first few episodes, honestly! There were some good matches and some bad ones. I know it's a reality TV show so people will be dramatic and there'll be arguments but it felt like most of them were just being mean to each other for no reason. For example, Janet told Marshall she was going to hate him after he said that thing he said about her in front of their friends. Seriously?! And why did they even let her on the show if she was going to treat people like that?  And then there's Nick and Alexa. Honestly, how can someone fall in love with someone who doesn't say "I love you"? It feels kinda weird to me. I hope they make it through this season though because they seem nice when they're together.

title: What's the deal with "unholy" in the lyrics?
self_text: Is it an actual word, or is it just there to sound intense/evil?  I get that it's a metaphor for evil, but it sounds like a real word and I don't know what it means.   It's used at the end of the song on the album as well, so it must be important.

We have tried the living room, the dining room, and the bedroom, but nothing seems right. It feels like we’re being judged by our neighbors or that we’re disturbing them in some way. Is there anywhere else we could pray? Thank you for your time.

Or would it only amplify the hatred and division that already exists?  I feel like it might be possible for everyone to have some sort of connection because we are all human.   What do you think?

title: Any of you ever had an experience with the term “shadow” or any related imagery?
self_text: I was watching a documentary about the history of the Catholic Church and it kept bringing up the topic of shadow play. At first, I thought they were just referring to a form of performance art but then they began talking about how people in the church would go to the mountains to play games involving light and shadow. They claimed that it was for spiritual purification but it sounded like some kind of ritualistic game involving death.  I’ve been reading up on this stuff lately and it seems like there's a huge amount of symbolism involved with the idea of “shadow”. It seems like the whole idea is based around coming to terms with the darkness within oneself—which is a pretty heavy concept!   So, has anyone ever experienced something similar or had thoughts about the term/imagery?  It’s kinda stuck with me since I started watching this documentary.

Since then I have been doing a lot of research on other religions. Now I believe the Bible is true but Catholicism isn’t correct. I don’t know if I am ready for a full conversion yet but it feels like I'm closer than ever. I pray every day and feel more and more connected to God with each passing day. My questions are how long will it take me to be fully converted and what would I do next?   Thank you all in advance!

title: Unbelievable, I can't believe it's already been 3 years since my wife passed away.
self_text: It feels like yesterday and a lifetime ago all at the same time. I still see her everywhere and hear her voice in my head.  I hope she knows how much I loved her and will always love her. She was the best woman I knew.   I just wish that we could have had more time together.   It's hard to move on when you are still grieving someone who has been such an important part of your life. But I know that it will get easier eventually.   Rest in peace, my beautiful wife. You were and always will be my everything.

title: What’s the deal with the “Blessed Unbroken” and the “Blessed Darkened”?
self_text: So I’m looking for a specific type of book here, namely a book where there’s a strong connection between the main character (or characters) and the devil/demons.   I’ve read a lot of books about the Catholic Church in general, but not much about the Devil or Demons in particular.  I’ve heard that the Blessed Unbroken is written by a former exorcist, which is interesting to me because it seems like he was dealing with demons frequently.   Also, I just found out that the Blessed Darkened is written by the same guy who wrote the Blessed Unbroken, so I figured I’d ask this question here since I know people here are pretty knowledgeable about Catholicism.   Are these books connected?   Does the author have any other writings on similar topics?   Would you recommend them to someone interested in demonic encounters?

title: Any Muslims who had an epiphany about Islam?
self_text: I recently met a Muslim man at work and he was telling me his story about how he came to convert to Islam. He said he had been raised Catholic, but he didn't believe in any religion.  He said that after the death of his father he went through some dark times. Then he stumbled upon Islam and it just felt right.  He talked about how he felt like he finally had an answer for life and death.  I’m just curious if anyone here has gone through something similar?   It feels like most people have had a big reason or event trigger their faith, but I feel like sometimes it is just a quiet realization.

title: What if I told you that the Islamic State group had been trying to hack into the US government for years?
self_text: A recent article from The New York Times reveals that a group of hackers with ties to ISIS tried to hack into the US government in 2019, and they were able to get in. According to the article, the hackers managed to get past several layers of security before being stopped by an FBI agent named Robert Hill. The article also states that the hackers used sophisticated hacking techniques, including ransomware and phishing scams.  The story is so intriguing because it shows how far ISIS’s reach has gone. It was thought that their operations were limited to Syria and Iraq, but the fact that they were able to try to hack into the US government proves that they have resources and connections that go beyond what people realize.  The story also raises questions about whether the US government has been doing enough to protect itself from cyberattacks.  It is important to note that this story comes from The New York Times, which is a reputable news source. However, it is still worth taking it with a grain of salt, as there is always the possibility that the information could be inaccurate or incomplete. Nevertheless, the story is certainly worth reading.  Here's the link to the article: https://www.nytimes.com/2023/07/28/us/isis-hackers-government-security.html #ISIS #cyberattack #hacking #USgovernment

title: Is there a way to get rid of the religious indoctrination in my family?
self_text: I was raised by a very devout Christian family and all I've ever known is that Jesus died for our sins and we need to pray to him every day. This has been drilled into me since childhood, and now that I am older, it feels like an obligation rather than a faith.  I’m not sure what to do because my parents will be extremely upset if I say I don’t believe in God anymore or stop praying. They are going to assume I have gone to hell (or worse).  So, how can I get out of the religion while still being able to live with them peacefully? I just want to find out why I really believe the things I do, so maybe I can change my mind.   Can anyone help me with this?

title: Can you feel the shift in power from a religious object?
self_text: I have been getting into my mom’s old prayer beads and they are really beautiful, but when I hold them for a long time, I can start to get really anxious and confused about myself. Like if I am in doubt about something or have no idea what to do, holding these beads makes me more uneasy.  I know it sounds dumb, but is there any chance that the beads could be affecting me somehow? Maybe because of their history, or something like that?   I don't want to disrespect my mom or her religion, so please let me know if you think I should be worried.

title: What if the prophecy was wrong?
self_text: The Book of Revelation is a long, convoluted book that describes events to come in the end times. It's written in symbolic language and can be interpreted differently by different people. However, most Christians believe that it’s a very accurate description of what will happen. And yet, there are many issues with the book itself. For example, the main issue with the book is that it says that God will destroy the earth during the end times. But the Bible also says that God will preserve his followers and create a new heaven and a new earth for them. So how could these two things happen at the same time?

title: What do you think about the "last day of Ramadan" in Turkey?
self_text: I have seen some videos and discussions on Twitter, mostly from Muslim people who live in Turkey. Most of them are saying that they will be very sad if it's cancelled or moved earlier. They say that many Muslims in Turkey see this day as a symbol of their faith, a day for reflection and gratitude. Some people also say that if we cancel it, then what's next? When will they stop doing religious stuff?  I don't understand why there is such a big fuss around just one day. It feels like a way to manipulate people into believing something.   What do you think about this? Is this really important for Turkish Muslims? Do you think it should be cancelled or not?

It's not that I feel confused, but just...a lot of thoughts.  I'm an atheist with no religious beliefs, but I am trying to understand what people believe in.  What are your thoughts?

title: “Unbelievably” I’m on a spiritual journey that is only beginning…
self_text: I was raised Catholic and went to mass with my family every Sunday. I never really felt anything, just like it was something you had to do for your parents.  Then when I got older I started going by myself and still didn't feel anything.   But then one day I read the Bible and something just clicked in me… I was instantly moved to tears. It wasn’t just reading words, but feeling God’s love through Jesus Christ.  I am now on a spiritual journey of learning about Him and I know He is real and loves me.   It feels as though God has been waiting for me to start this journey and he’s so happy I’m finally here.   What do I do next?  How can I deepen my relationship with him?  Where can I find more information about Him? What are some things to avoid?    Thank you, God Bless!

title: Has anyone ever had a religious experience?
self_text: I’m not sure if I’m going crazy or not but lately, I have been experiencing something that is hard to describe. It’s like when you are in the middle of an amazing concert and everything just blends together into a single feeling of pure joy and excitement. For me, it's happened when I am praying. It’s very brief but there is a sense of connection with something bigger than myself. I feel like I was made for something more and this is the first step to finding it. I know it sounds weird and it could be my mind playing tricks on me. But I thought I would ask here since most people who have spiritual experiences believe in God.   Has anyone ever experienced something like this before? What did you do after? Did it lead you to faith? Or was it just a fleeting moment of peace? I don't want to go off the deep end so please give me your honest opinion.  Thanks!

title: I can’t find a good video about the end of season 3, so here is my take on it.
self_text: I feel like it’s a big cop out by the writers and they just wanted to wrap things up quickly. It feels like after all that buildup in season 2 with the revelation of Nick’s role as an informant, and the fact that he was married to Lisa and had a child with her, that it should have been more emotional. Instead, they decided to just let him die off screen. I understand why they did it (Lisa’s obsession), but they could have done a better job writing it.  I also don’t think the ending was good because it’s the last episode ever. The showrunners must have felt like it would be difficult to come up with something compelling for the final episode, so they went for the easiest option which is killing off Nick. He never got a proper sendoff.  The biggest problem is that the show felt like it was going nowhere at the end of season 2. It had no direction anymore, and nothing seemed to matter anymore. Lisa was obsessed with finding Nick, even though she knew he was dead. She didn't give up and continue trying to solve his case. And you know what?   It’s fine. They were clearly not thinking about the finale when they wrote season 2, so it doesn't really matter. What matters is how much we loved season 2.

title: What if I had been born in a Muslim country?
self_text: Okay, so this is a weird thought experiment but hear me out. My mom was born in Morocco and my dad was from the UK. So basically, my family has an Islamic background.  However, when I was born, I was registered as a Christian because my mom wanted to give me a "better" life. She said that it would be easier for me to live in Europe than in Morocco. And she said that I'd have more opportunities to be successful. She really didn't want me to grow up being poor and struggling with no education.   She’s very religious and still prays to God every day. But I grew up being raised Christian, and I went to church every Sunday. I even took holy communion. The thing is, I never felt like I believed in Christianity. I always knew that something was missing.   I also know that my mom is a good person. It’s just… she doesn’t understand why I feel so conflicted about my religion. Maybe she thinks I’m trying to go against her or hurt her feelings. She keeps saying “You are blessed by God”.  But honestly, what if I had been born in a Muslim country? Would I be different? Would I have more connections to my heritage? Would I have been able to build a better life for myself? Would my mom have been happier?  I don’t know! I am just curious about what might have happened if I had been born in a Muslim country.

title: “I’m not the same person I was when I first started playing video games” - Dave Baazmeen
self_text: A quote from a new indie game that I just played. It really hit home, since I’ve been thinking about it lately.  It’s so weird how we can change over time. We might think we still have the same interests and hobbies but in reality we don't.  Maybe you used to be obsessed with a certain music genre or artist, but now you hate it. Maybe you used to love a certain sport or activity but now you find it boring.   That’s just how people are though.  The point of my saying this is that I’ve been wondering if you will ever be the same person again.  I know things change over time. But am I scared of your future? Or do I feel like you won’t remember me? If you could give me an idea on why you feel that way I would appreciate it. Also, I want to know what kind of music you listen to these days…  You also mentioned something earlier that I didn’t quite get, which was: “I’ll never forget you”. That’s a pretty big statement.  What did you mean by that? Did you always see our relationship as something special? You said you were going to be a musician.  Did you ever get around to writing any songs?

title: “The Return of the King” and a Prayerful Heart (Part 1)
self_text: Hello, friends! I’m writing this to share my recent experience with an intense spiritual growth period and how it was connected to the film “The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King.” It wasn't something that happened suddenly; it was a gradual process—a slow, quiet shift in my heart. I’ve been reading the book for years, but recently I decided to watch the movie again, intending to simply enjoy the beautiful scenery and the epic battle scenes. However, as I watched the final scene where Frodo finally casts the Ring into Mount Doom, something profound shifted within me. I felt an overwhelming sense of peace, and a deep recognition that the story had been more than just entertainment. It had been an invitation. A prayerful invitation to connect with something far greater than myself.  I know, it sounds cheesy, but I want to explain.   My Spiritual Journey Begins... My journey started about six months ago when I went through a period of depression. I lost my job, my boyfriend left me, and my mother passed away from cancer.   After a few months of feeling like nothing mattered, I realized I needed to make a change. I needed to reconnect with God, and I began attending church again.  However, there were times I would have doubts. Times when I didn’t feel anything or when things would get difficult. Sometimes I would feel angry at God. Why did He let my mom die? Why did He take my job? Why did He let my boyfriend leave me? What good could come out of all of this?  Then I thought, "Maybe if I didn't pray to Him, He would not be able to help me." So I began to pray to God every single day. I would go outside, sit on my porch, and just talk to Him. At first, I talked about my problems. But as I continued to pray, I realized that He wanted me to praise Him.   It’s funny because I used to think that praising God was only for people who were happy and content. But I learned that even when you're going through the darkest times, you can still find beauty and gratitude in God's creation. I’d sit on my porch and look up at the sky, watching the clouds move by, and I would say, “Thank you, God, for the beauty of your world.”   This simple act of gratitude changed everything.   As I continued to focus on praising God, I noticed that my thoughts became calmer and clearer. I was less anxious and depressed. I found a new job, and a new friend who helped me heal. I also came to terms with my mother’s passing.  I still don’t understand why God allows suffering, but I believe that He is always working behind the scenes, even when we can’t see it. And I believe that His love is stronger than any pain.

title: I feel like there’s no way to do a good deed without someone turning it around on you.
self_text: If I help someone out, they always try to turn the favor around or find something wrong with me. It makes me wonder if people are just trying to take advantage of my kindness.

title: Is it possible to go back in time and change the past?
self_text: I've been reading about paradoxes, particularly the grandfather paradox and bootstrap paradoxes, and they make me think if it's possible to travel back in time and change the past. If you could go back in time and change something that happened in the past, would it affect the present?  For example, let's say you went back in time and prevented your parents from meeting each other. Would you cease to exist? Or would a new timeline be created? I also wonder how much of our past is already written and set in stone?

title: Game of Thrones Season 8 was a terrible decision and the writing was atrocious.
self_text: I feel like if they had made some changes to the story, it would have been a good season. The biggest issue with the show is that in the books they do not die the way that they did in the final season. Cersei dies when she is fighting on her knees at the base of the Iron Throne. Arya kills her. And Sansa makes peace with Littlefinger after he betrayed everyone else. This last one is the most important thing because the ending felt so rushed. In the books we see how far she has come as a ruler. She gets married off again and rules over the North. But by the time the book ends she is well on her way to being a good queen.   I feel like if the writers wanted to give us something bad, then just make a terrible show. They ruined such an amazing show for no reason.

title: Is it possible to have a “post-partum” experience with an adopted child?
self_text: I am wondering if there are any similarities between having a biological child and an adopted child.  I’m a first time mom, and my husband and I adopted our son from Korea when he was 6 months old. He is now 18 months old.   We are just trying to figure out how to best provide for his needs, but the main thing that I struggle with is this feeling of sadness/grief over not being able to give him life before.  I am wondering if there are any similar feelings when you adopt a child, or when you raise your children.

title: What if my parents were Muslim and I was raised as a Muslim?
self_text: My family has been Catholic since the beginning of time, but there have been times when we’ve had Muslim friends over or talked to them about their religion.  I found out that they are devout Muslims and live their lives according to their beliefs.  They never made me feel like I should convert, but it got me thinking about what would happen if I had grown up in a Muslim household.  Would I be a Muslim too? Would I even know how to practice Islam?  It's just something that crossed my mind recently because I was watching some videos about Islamic culture.  I don't know how to answer this question because I don't really know anything about Islam beyond what I've learned from my friends.  I guess it would depend on what kind of family I was raised in, but I bet most people would probably be Muslim.  What do you guys think?

title: "The Night" - A Very Long Time Ago
self_text: My dad, who was a devout Muslim and used to pray 5 times a day and fast for Ramadan, had a very close relationship with his younger brother. This brother, Hassan, had been raised in a Christian household and Hassan was always the one to invite him to church, to go on picnics, etc.   One day, my Dad came home from work and said he felt like he needed to confess something to me, which was shocking because it's been over 30 years since he last spoke about this event. He told me that when he was younger, he was having an affair with his brother Hassan’s wife. It was a long time ago—the late seventies.  It happened only once, and they both agreed never to speak of it again.   My dad then said that he felt it was important for me to know as he realized that his faith had been shaken ever since. I tried to be understanding but I couldn't stop feeling so hurt. I felt betrayed by someone who supposedly loved me and who taught me to love Islam. I asked why he did what he did, and he simply said he was young and stupid, and that it wasn't a big deal.   I immediately became angry and said I didn’t believe him and that he was lying. I ended up crying and screaming at him. He apologized profusely, saying that he wished he could take it back, but that he knows he can't.   That night, I went to bed and cried myself to sleep.   He never brought it up again. But I’ve carried this guilt with me ever since.   Now, 20 years later, my mom passed away, leaving me alone in the family house. I found a box of old photos and letters and stumbled upon some evidence to support my dad’s confession. Pictures of him holding hands with Hassan’s wife, and letters between them. It confirmed that what he said was true. I still feel heartbroken and confused. Why did he do this? What was going through his mind?  How can I forgive him after all these years?

title: Does anyone else have a lot of trouble when they try to make sense of the Bible?
self_text: I’m not saying that it's hard, but my parents always made me read the bible and memorize verses, and I never really understood what any of it meant or why we were supposed to be reading it. Now I'm trying to learn about it for myself, which is kind of an interesting process to go through. It just seems like the older versions are full of contradictions and nonsense. For example, in Genesis, God created Adam and Eve from dust. However, if you look at the New Testament, he created them from the dirt. And then there are all these other things that seem to conflict with each other.   I'm trying to come to terms with the fact that I was raised as a Christian, but I don't really believe anything that comes out of the Bible anymore.  I'm wondering whether that's okay though, and whether I should just give up on being Christian altogether.   I've heard some people say that the reason that many Christians can't seem to find any meaning in the bible is because they haven't read it correctly or because they aren't truly seeking God.  But I'm starting to think that it may just be because the old versions of the bible are so confusing and contradictory. Do you guys know of any good resources for learning more about the Bible? Is there anything that I can do to help me understand it better?

title: What if Islam had embraced Christianity?
self_text: I was thinking about what would happen if the muslims had converted to christianity in the first place, instead of vice versa.  I believe it would have been a very different world, and probably for the better.  With that being said, here are my thoughts on how it would be different:   The Crusades never happened as they did.   Instead, there'd be no religious wars at all, since the holy sites wouldn't be contested by either side.   Islam would have spread more quickly and efficiently across Europe, because you’d have no resistance from Christian kingdoms.  It is possible, and even likely, that the Ottoman Empire would never have risen to power or ever occurred.   The Americas might have been colonized by the Christian European nations, like Spain or Portugal, instead of the Muslim ones.    However, with no Islamic empire, you may not have seen as much trade between Europe and Asia.   Perhaps many Europeans would still be stuck in the Middle Ages, rather than experiencing the Renaissance.   Also, without Islam, countries like Saudi Arabia and Egypt could have never existed.   I am just brainstorming here, so please feel free to correct me if I am wrong.   What do you guys think?   Do you think the world would be a better place if Islam had embraced Christianity?

title: A brief summary of the book “The Book of Life”
self_text: I just finished reading “The Book of Life” by Chris Hebert and it was an amazing story!  I know there are a lot of other people out there that have read the book, but for those who haven’t, here is a quick summary of the book in case you were interested in giving it a read:   “The Book of Life” follows the life of Jacob, who struggles with severe depression and anxiety.  After his parents die, he becomes estranged from his siblings and feels lost and alone.  His sister, Rachel, comes to visit him and they end up going on a trip to see all of the places where their parents lived. They take along their friends, Chloe, and Ben, as they travel through the states and try to find some meaning and purpose in their lives.  As they go to each location, they uncover more about their family history, which leads them to believe that their parents had been living double lives.  They learn that their father was actually a spy during World War II and worked for the US government. The mother also had a secret past, but she had been working undercover for the CIA.  Their parents used these fake identities to protect themselves and their families from harm. It turns out that Jacob's grandmother was part of the CIA too and her brother was a German spy.  At the end of the book, Jacob and his siblings come to terms with their family history and realize that they can move forward together.

title: Does anyone else have an issue with how the end of season 2 was written?
self_text: I mean, come on! The ending of season 2 was so anticlimactic. Like, after everything that happened in season 2, they had to just write a super depressing and unsatisfying ending for the season. It’s like they didn’t even care about the characters or the story.   The biggest thing is the whole thing with Nick and Lisa. Like, what the heck was that?! They never said anything about them being together, it was just suddenly there. I mean, did we not see any of their interactions throughout the season? They were barely around each other, let alone doing something as serious as getting married. It felt like they just threw it in at the end of the season for no reason whatsoever.  It also feels so random. Like, why would Nick be so interested in Lisa? She's literally nothing like him. And why does she want to marry him? What's she thinking? It just doesn't make sense. I don’t understand what the point of writing that scene was. It was just such a waste of time and energy.

title: Is there a way to fix my broken motherboard?
self_text: My PC is dead and I'm not sure what to do, so here's the situation.  I was playing CS2 on my PC when it suddenly shut off and never turned back on. I tried everything, like checking for loose cables, making sure the power supply had enough juice, etc. But nothing worked. Then, I took my PSU out of the case and plugged in another cable from the wall to see if that was the issue, but still no luck.   So I went ahead and opened up the case and checked all the connections on the motherboard. Turns out that the CPU fan connector isn't connected.  I plugged it into the correct port on the motherboard and then reinstalled drivers for the CPU.  Then I started my PC again and it shut down immediately. I figured something broke with the motherboard. So I looked online at the motherboard and saw that the CPU fan connector doesn't have any pins on them. It looks like someone tried to connect it to the wrong port.  Now the question is: Can I fix this? Or does it need to be replaced?

title: The most important thing to remember when going through a divorce is that you have the power to choose your future…
self_text: …and to believe in yourself and that it’s okay to ask for help along the way. If you need support or just someone to talk to, please reach out to a trusted friend, family member, counselor, or therapist. You are not alone! It’s okay to be vulnerable and let others know how you’re feeling.  There are many resources available to help you through this difficult time, such as grief counseling, anger management classes, support groups, etc. Don’t be afraid to use them. And if you need to go back to the past, there are ways to do so—for example, therapy can help you work through things that are causing you to relive those times over and over again.   Most importantly, don’t give up on yourself. Even though it may feel like everything is falling apart, there is hope for the future. Believe in yourself and that you are capable of overcoming any obstacle.  You deserve happiness and peace.
